articles.title: Study: Duration of Heat Waves Accelerating Faster Than Global Warming
articles.author: Contributing Editor
articles.summary: UCLA and the Universidad Adolfo Ibaí±ez in Santiago, Chile, conducted a study on the effects of climate change on heat waves. They found that the longest heat waves will see the greatest acceleration, and the frequency of the most blistering heatwaves will increase the most. Future research is dependent on federal budgets.

articles.title: UCLA Study: Duration of Heat Waves Accelerating Faster Than Global Warming
articles.author: City News Service
articles.summary: UCLA and the Universidad Adolfo Ibañez in Santiago, Chile, found that the longest heat waves will see the greatest acceleration due to climate change. The duration of a heat wave exacerbates the risk to people, animals, agriculture and ecosystems. Future research dependent on federal budgets.

articles.title: Tracking ice, tracking change: Satellite data reveal how melting glaciers reshape landscapes
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Across Europe and around the world, melting glaciers are reshaping landscapes and climate systems. Researchers Elzė Buslavičiūtė and Dr. Laurynas Jukna study the effects of melting glaciers on the environment and climate system.

articles.title: Spain's Costa Blanca bears the scars of a real estate frenzy
articles.author: Sandrine Morel
articles.summary: Photographer and filmmaker Markel Redondo traveled across the region of Valencia from 2020 to 2021 to create a series La idea de éxito ("The idea of success"). He explored the relationship between people and urbanized landscapes in Castillos de arena ("Sandcastles").

articles.title: Fire held in Merritt off Trans Canada Highway
articles.author: Jennifer Smith
articles.summary: A wildfire off Highway 5 near Merritt is being held. Firefighters are on scene of the blaze, which was sparked around 3 p.m. Tuesday, July 8. The fire is estimated .009 hectares in size and labelled Fox Farm Road. The cause is under investigation.

articles.title: OBR: Economic cost of climate change likely 'more severe' than previously thought
articles.author: Jane Thynne
articles.summary: An increase in global temperatures of close to 3C above pre-industrial levels would damage Britain's economy more than previously assumed. According to the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR), this is because of the negative impact on the economy of such a rise in temperature.

articles.title: Antarctica's Volcanic Awakening: A Cascade of Eruptions Threatens to Unfold as Ice Recedes
articles.summary: There is a direct link between melting glaciers and the potential reawakening of dormant volcanoes worldwide. Research focused on the Chilean Andes suggests that the diminishing ice mass is reducing the pressure on underlying magma chambers, increasing the risk of eruptions. The relationship between glacial melt and volcanic eruptions is complex but increasingly understood. Communities near volcanoes should prepare for the possibility of renewed activity and develop thorough evacuation plans.

articles.title: Unicoi County Schools leaders pleased with TCAP scores despite challenging year
articles.author: Karen Jenkins
articles.summary: Unicoi County students missed 30 instructional days due to the floods of Hurricane Helene and the winter's snow. Scores for ELA improved by 10.7% from last year, math scores rose 2.1%, science scores were up 3.2%, and social studies students improved the most with a 20.2% performance increase. Third-grade test scores dropped by 4%, but 37 students who appealed their scores due to hardships from the hurricane will be promoted to fourth grade.

articles.title: The Earth's Rotation Is About to Spin Up So Much That Tomorrow Will Be Much Shorter Than Today
articles.author: Victor Tangermann
articles.summary: July 9, July 22, and August 5 of this year will be some of the shortest days in recent memory. The Earth's rotation is about to accelerate significantly. Since 1972, scientists have sliced a "leap second" from the clock a whopping 27 times thanks to a steady deceleration.

articles.title: Scientists Puzzled by Earth's Rotation Speed Suddenly Increasing, Leading to Unexpectedly Short Days
articles.summary: July 9, July 22, and August 5 of this year will be some of the shortest days in recent memory. The Earth's rotation is about to accelerate. Since 1972, scientists have sliced a "leap second" from the clock a whopping 27 times thanks to a steady deceleration.

articles.title: Bogotá's Mobility Transformation: A July 8 Update
articles.summary: There is a surge in heavy rainfall across Colombia. The current weather pattern is linked to the ongoing La Niña phenomenon, which typically brings increased rainfall to the northern parts of South America. The increased rainfall has already led to the overflow of several rivers and streams, causing localized flooding in urban and rural areas. Road closures are reported in multiple locations due to landslides and debris. The government has allocated additional resources to support emergency response efforts and is working with local authorities to implement preventative measures.

articles.title: Lizard Island Great Barrier Reef Loses 92% Corals in 2024 Bleaching
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: Lizard Island on Australia's Great Barrier Reef has suffered one of the world's worst coral die-offs since the 2024 bleaching event. 96% of corals were bleached and mortality averaged 92%. Some sites lost over 99%. The study's lead researcher Vincent Raoult described the mortality as "unprecedented".

articles.title: Guardian: European Heatwave Failing to Spur Support for Climate Action
articles.author: Eric Worrall
articles.summary: Eric Worrall's essay explains why people are less concerned about climate change and more concerned about other issues like the cost of living, immigration and the NHS. He suggests that the main reason for the drop in climate concern is that ordinary people have to prioritise short term survival over their climate concerns.

articles.title: As Glaciers Retreat, Powerful Volcanoes May Erupt More Frequently Across the Planet
articles.author: Stephanie Edwards
articles.summary: As glaciers retreat due to climate change, volcanoes are likely to erupt more frequently and more explosively. The research project focused on six volcanoes located in the Chilean Andes where the Patagonian Ice Sheet has advanced and retreated over time. The study also provided new understandings of volcano behavior and how to better predict when a volcano may become active relative to glacial melting.

articles.title: Bilawal grieves over loss of lives in rain-related incidents across country
articles.author: Sajid Salamat
articles.summary: Bilawal Bhutto Zardari has expressed profound sorrow and heartfelt condolences over the loss of precious lives and widespread damage to property caused by rain-related incidents in various parts of the country, including Balochistan, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and the twin cities of Islamabad and Rawalpindi. He called for the National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) and the Provincial Disaster Management Agency (PDMA) to jointly initiate relief operations in the rain-affected districts.

articles.title: Why Some Young Australians Avoid AI: The Reason Behind This Photo
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Some young Australians are choosing not to use generative AI tools like ChatGPT or Google Gemini due to concerns about their potential environmental impact. Generative AI models need a lot of computational power to run, so they rely on data centres. Data centres consumed more electricity than all of Australia in 2022.

articles.title: Column - Global warming is a threat to all
articles.author: Staff Reports
articles.summary: Earth is warming faster than it did in the past. There's been a rise in sea level by 7-8 inches since 1900. Mass coral bleaching events have become five times more common worldwide over the past 40 years. Global floods and extreme rainfall have increased by more than 50% in the last decade. We need to limit the rise in global temperature to 1.5 degrees Centigrade (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit).

articles.title: Nandidurga Road gets 10 saplings; motorists get new obstacles
articles.author: DHNS
articles.summary: The move has irked others, who believe the saplings encroach upon road space and pose risks to motorists as they grow bigger. The saplings could damage the surface and pose a risk to motorists if they grow too big for the road.

articles.title: Tuvalu: The World's Smallest Country Faces Extinction As Rising Seas Swallow Nation
articles.author: R. J. Manuel
articles.summary: The island nation of Tuvalu is one of the most vulnerable countries to climate change. It is the fourth-smallest country in the world by land area, measuring just 26 square kilometers (10 square miles). It consists of nine coral atolls and reef islands scattered across the Pacific Ocean. Its highest point is less than 5 meters above sea level, making the entire country susceptible to minor rises in ocean levels. Scientists warn that if current trends in global warming continue, large parts of the country could become uninhabitable within the next 20 to 30 years. The government initiated a project in 2022 aimed at establishing the world's first digital nation.

articles.title: Aron's Down Under from Denmark
articles.author: Adam Palombi
articles.summary: Aron Jurak, 17, is returning home after a year-long stay in Yarrawonga, Australia. He visited the Great Barrier Reef, Jarvis Bay, Uluru and the Northern Territory. He trained with the Mulwala Lions and saw the Geelong Cats play at the MCG. He wants to study bioengineering or become a veterinarian.

articles.title: Eno Arts Mill closes indefinitely after Chantal flooding, Orange County officials say
articles.author: Matthew Sockol
articles.summary: The home of the Orange County Arts Commission is closed indefinitely because of flooding from Tropical Depression Chantal. The Eno Arts Mill was damaged by the flooding and will need to be demolished and restored. Several artists lost decades of work because of the flooding. Anyone who wishes to support the artists can visit the Orange Country Arts Commission website.

articles.title: Earth's Rotation To Force Shorter Days This Summer. Here's Why
articles.author: Matt Wadleigh
articles.summary: Earth's rotation will make the days shorter on July 9, July 22 and August 5 because the Earth will be spinning faster than normal. The position of the moon is expected to affect Earth's rotation so that each day is between 1.3 and 1.51 milliseconds shorter than normal on these dates.

articles.title: Congress must make America more resilient to increasingly devastating disasters
articles.author: Rep. Yvette D. Clarke
articles.summary: According to an internal review, the Federal Emergency Management Agency isn't ready to help Americans this year. Trump plans to dismantle the agency entirely by December. Since 1979, FEMA has been a life-saving service, helping Americans get through the worst of a disaster. The last couple of years have broken historical records for the total number of billion-dollar disasters from extreme weather due to global warming.

articles.title: Authorities searching for missing 23-year-old woman reported missing in Graham: Police
articles.author: Jeremy Vernon
articles.summary: Alamance County officials are searching for a 23-year-old woman who went missing during heavy rains caused by Tropical Storm Chantal in Graham, N.C. The woman has not been identified yet.    .

articles.title: Eastern states shivered through a chilly June, is a warmer winter still on the cards?
articles.author: Tyne Logan
articles.summary: It is two weeks past the winter solstice and many parts of Australia have been feeling the cold. It is the 48th coldest June on record, but not the coldest by historical standards. Since 1910, Australia's average temperature has warmed by more than 1.5C, which means all seasons are getting warmer on average.

articles.title: Carl Edsel Murray, 88
articles.author: Www.Wydaily.Com Http
articles.summary: Carl Edsel Murray, 88, passed from his earthly life to his eternal rest Sunday, July 6, 2025 at Lower Cape Fear LifeCare in Wilmington. Carl was born March 17, 1937, in Pender County, North Carolina, the son of Bruce Murray and Rena Marshburn Murray. Carl is survived by his daughter Donna Murray Burnette (Clinton Ray), his granddaughter Shelby Burnette, and his brother Milton Murray. For a number of years, Carl served proudly in the NC National Guard and was a member of Mt. Holly Baptist Church. The funeral service will take place on Wednesday, July 9, 2025, at 12:00 p.m. at Quinn-McGowen

articles.title: Commentary: The Texas floods were made worse by climate denialism
articles.author: Michael R. Bloomberg

The Trump administration is actively thwarting efforts to address climate change and help communities cope with its harms.

articles.summary: Sustainability Magazine claims that human-caused climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of heat waves, which are placing strain on power grids worldwide. Data does not support the notion that heat waves are increasing in frequency or intensity on a global scale. Evidence suggests that localized temperature increases are driven by the Urban Heat Island (UHI) effect, not global climate change. The article's claim that 2025 has already seen heat waves striking China, the United States, Canada, France, and the United Kingdom is presented as though this constitutes evidence of a crisis.

articles.author: Satyaki Baidya
articles.summary: Ice cover delays volcanic eruptions, allowing magma to build up heat and pressure underground. When released, this leads to far more powerful and destructive explosions. Scientists warn that this marks the beginning of a perilous chain reaction with the potential to affect the entire planet.

articles.title: Staying inside and cattle dying: the real risks of climate change to UK
articles.author: Jane Merrick
articles.summary: People in the UK could be forced to stay at home to shelter from extreme weather due to climate change, according to the government's Chronic Risks Analysis. The document is a 132-page detailed assessment of persistent threats facing the country, from artificial intelligence to terrorism.

articles.title: Climate shocks threaten livelihood patterns of Bengaluru's communities, finds report
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: Report by Bengaluru Sustainability Forum (BSF) and Socratus highlights the impact of climate change on the city's vulnerable communities. The report highlights how poor housing conditions heightened climate risk. It also points to how damage to housing caused significant mental and financial distress among communities. Water insecurity was another factor which increased vulnerability and lower adaptive capacities of communities.

DeLand might still pride itself as a caring community-oriented town, but Big Money has a different priority.

Jetstar and Qantas flights are expected to operate as normal.

articles.title: Africa's most disaster prone country - and it's not one you might expect
articles.author: Schannell Kanyora
articles.summary: Mozambique has a World Risk Index Total (WRI) of 34.4. This is calculated by the geometric mean of a country's exposure to natural hazards and its vulnerability. Mozambique is highly susceptible to natural disasters due to a combination of geographical, climatic, and socio-economic factors.

articles.title: Intense downpours like those in Texas are more frequent, but there's no telling where they'll happen

articles.title: Kashmir's summer sizzle: AC sales soar as valley copes with record temperatures
articles.author: Nh Digital
articles.summary: Kashmir has experienced unprecedented temperature spikes this year. On 5 July, Srinagar recorded 37.4°C, the highest July temperature in over 70 years. In June, Qazigund and Kupwara saw temperatures climb 6–8°C above normal, prompting the IMD to issue heatwave warnings.

articles.title: What are the UK weather records for July?
articles.author: Ian Jones
articles.summary: Temperatures above 40C have been officially recorded anywhere in the country for the first time in the history of the country, and so far only the date on which it was recorded in the UK. It was the highest temperature ever recorded in this part of the world.

articles.title: Climate crisis hits critical tipping point as temperatures soar
articles.author: bnm Gulf bureau
articles.summary: According to Ahad Vazifeh, head of the National Climate Centre and Drought Crisis Management at the Meteorological Organisation, Iran's average temperature has increased between 2 to 2.5 degrees Celsius over the past 50 years, reaching 3 degrees in central plateau regions. Annual rainfall in Iran has declined from 255mm in past decades to around 200mm currently, and evaporation potential has increased from approximately 1,100mm in the past to 1,350mm. If current conditions are not controlled and temperatures rise by 8 degrees, many cities bordering deserts will no longer have suitable living conditions.

articles.title: New Study: The Arctic Was 9°C Warmer Than Today During The Holocene Thermal Maximum
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: Holocene (11,700 to 8,200 years ago) Arctic temperatures were up to 9°C higher than today. Svalbard then cooled as CO2 rose for the next 8,000 years. This contradicts the rising-CO2-drives-Arctic-warmth narrative.

articles.title: Not all species flee heat: New hypothesis explains surprising movements in nature
articles.author: Science X staff
articles.summary: As the climate warms, animals and plants are moving downhill, toward the equator or into shallower waters. Scientists from UNSW Sydney argue that as the climate changes, so too does the relationships between species. Understanding these dynamics is crucial for conservationists and land managers trying to predict how wildlife will respond to global warming.

articles.title: Why is the Earth spinning faster? Is time speeding up? Australia's experts give us their second opinion
articles.author: Petra Stock
articles.summary: On 9 July, 22 July and 5 August, the Earth's rotation will quicken relative to the sun, truncating the days by a millisecond or more. Before the 1950s, the length of a day was defined by the Earth’s rotation and the apparent position of the sun. Today, the institute keeps track of time using atomic clocks, which are synchronised globally to Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

articles.title: Climate change is slowing Earth's spin: How melting ice and shifting water are subtly stretching our days
articles.author: Divya Danu
articles.summary: In 2020, Earth was spinning faster than at any point since records began in the 1970s. On July 5, 2024, we had the shortest recorded day, which was 1.66 milliseconds shorter than the standard 24 hours. Earth's rotation is influenced by many forces, the moon, earthquakes, seasons, and now, climate change.

articles.title: Nags Head Democratic Precinct to host Public Meeting on Emergency Preparedness
articles.author: Submitted Story
articles.summary: Nags Head Democratic Precinct to host Public Meeting on Emergency Preparedness on July 10, 2025 at 6:00 p.m. at the Nags Head Town Hall Meeting Room. Special guest speaker is Drew Pearson, Emergency Management Director for Dare County. His presentation will focus on how Dare County is preparing for hurricane season.

articles.title: Manage disaster, reduce risks – government, coastal communities told
articles.author: Jonathan L. Mayuga
articles.summary: Oceana is calling on local government leaders to restore and protect mangrove forests and the establishment and management of local coastal greenbelt zones. Oceana believes that climate change is a serious threat to coastal communities and their livelihoods. This July is the National Disaster Resilience Month and World Mangrove Day.

articles.title: Shortest day in history set for TOMORROW as Earth's rotation unexpectedly speeds up
articles.author: CHRIS MELORE
articles.summary: Wednesday could be the shortest day of your life as Earth's rotation is expected to move quicker than ever before. Three days this summer, July 9, July 22, and August 5 are expected to be 1.3 to 1.51 milliseconds shorter than the standard day. The fastest day recorded so far was one year ago on July 5, 2024, when Earth spun 1.66 milliseconds faster than standard 24 hours. Earth recorded its shortest day on June 30.

articles.title: Extreme Heat Could Raise Death Risk For Pet Dogs By 10%, Warns Study
articles.author: Nikhil Pandey
articles.summary: Extreme heat can increase the risk of death in pet dogs by nearly 10%. The research highlights the growing dangers that human-induced climate change poses not just to people, but also to animals. The study analyzed 20 years of veterinary data from New South Wales and found that public holidays and Sundays carry the greatest risk for dogs.

articles.title: Wednesday will be 1.30 milliseconds shorter than 24 hours.
articles.author: طقس العرب
articles.summary: On Wednesday, July 9, 2025, Earth will witness a unique phenomenon: a day will be shorter than 24 hours due to a slight acceleration in Earth's rotation around its axis. People won't notice this change in their daily lives, but it is closely monitored by experts in earth sciences and timekeeping.

articles.title: Study: Melting Glaciers could cause more volcanic eruptions
articles.author: Andrew Sookdeo
articles.summary: The melting of glaciers due to climate change could make volcanic eruptions more catastrophic than before. The study placed six volcanoes in Chile under crystal analysis to determine how the shifting of the Patagonia Ice Sheet impacted the strength and frequency of previous eruptions. It found that following deglaciation, the volcano starts to erupt more often and changes composition.

articles.title: Earth to rotate faster, making some days slightly shorter in July and August

articles.title: Clarendon residents live in fear of rain

articles.title: Earth to spin faster this summer; three days will be shorter than normal
articles.author: Tags
articles.summary: Earth will spin faster on July 9, July 22, and August 5 this summer, making each day up to 1.51 milliseconds shorter than usual. The moon's position farthest from Earth's equator reduces gravitational drag on the planet. The Earth's rotation has been slowing over geologic time due to tidal friction caused by the moon's retreat, but recent observations reveal unexpected accelerations.

articles.title: Tundra fire on Alaska's North Slope is among the biggest in recent years

articles.title: Can you trust climate information? How and why powerful players are misleading the public

Their study found that the human response to the climate crisis is being obstructed by the production and circulation of misleading information.

articles.summary: The loss of ice releases the pressure on underground magma chambers and makes eruptions more likely, according to the study. The findings suggest volcanoes will erupt more frequently and more explosively.       .   "As glaciers retreat due to climate change, our findings suggest these volcanoes go on to erupt more often and explosively"

articles.title: Tackling Sindh's climate crisis
articles.author: Nasir Ali Panhwar
articles.summary: According to an intergovernmental panel on climate change, the least-developed and developing countries are expected to suffer more due to climate change than the developed ones. Pakistan's Sindh province is particularly vulnerable to natural disaster events due to its geographical location, socio-economic vulnerability, and climatic conditions. In 2022, Sindh received rainfall in excess of 400% over the 30-year average. Sindh has been disproportionately affected by the 2022 floods.

articles.author: Source: Xinhua

articles.title: Food insecure populations, June 2025
articles.author: Hillary Bett
articles.summary: Conflict, climate shocks, and economic instability are the main drivers of food insecurity in East and Central Africa. Sudan, South Sudan, Somalia, Ethiopia, and the Democratic Republic of Congo are most affected. Drought and flooding have severely impacted crop production and livestock. Displacement and limited humanitarian access worsened the crisis.
